facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 85 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CiVil Appeal No. 85 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 8, 1954 of High Court of Saurashtra in Civil Misc. Application No. 70 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 8, 1954, of the High Court of Saurashtra, at Rajkot, in Civil Misc. Application No. 70 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by BHAGWATI J. on November 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: 1956. November 23. The Judgment of the Court was, delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Saurashtra raises an interesting question whether the agarias working in the Salt Works at Kuda in the Rann of Cutch are workmen within the meaning of the term as defined in the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Appellants are lessees of the Salt Works from the erstwhile State of Dharangadhara and hold a licence for the manufacture of salt on the land.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are lessees of the Salt Works from the erstwhile State of Dharangadhara and also hold a licence for the manufacture of salt on the land.

facts.text: Appellants employ a Salt Superintendent who supervises the Salt Works.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants employ a Salt Superintendent who is in charge of the Salt Works and generally supervises the Works and the manufacture of salt carried on there.

facts.text: Salt operations are seasonal, commencing in October at the close of the monsoon and ending in June.

anchor.surface_text: The operations are seasonal in character and commence sometime in October at the close of the monsoon. Then the entire area is parceled out into plots called pattas and they are in four parallel rows intersected by the railway lines.

facts.text: Each agaria is allotted a patta, generally the same year after year.

anchor.surface_text: Each agaria is allotted a patta and in general the same patta is allotted to the same agaria year after year. If the patta is extensive it is allotted to two agarias who work the same in partnership.

facts.text: Appellants pay Rs. 400/- for each patta at allotment to meet initial expenses.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of such allotment, the appellants pay a sum of Rs. 400/- for each of the pattas and that is to meet the initial expenses. Then the agarias commence their work.

facts.text: Agarias level lands, enclose and sink wells in pattas.

anchor.surface_text: They level the lands and enclose and sink wells in them. Then the density of the water in the wells is examined by the Salt Superintendent of the appellants and then the brine is brought to the surface and collected in the reservoirs called condensers and re- tained therein until it acquires by natural process a certain amount of density.

facts.text: Salt Superintendent tests density, pans, and crystals.

anchor.surface_text: The pans have got to be prepared by the agarias according to certain standards and they are tested by the Salt Superintendent. When salt crystals begin to form in the pans they are again tested by the Salt Superintendent and only when they are of a particular quality the work of collecting salt is allowed to be commenced.

facts.text: Agarias paid Rs. 0-5-6 per maund for accepted salt; rejected salt belongs to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: if it is found to be of the right quality, the agarias are paid therefore at the rate of Rs. 0-5-6 per maund. Salt which is rejected belongs to the appellants and the agarias cannot either remove the salt manufactured by them or sell it.

facts.text: Final account settlement at end of season, balancing advances and dues.

anchor.surface_text: The account is made up at the end of the season when the advances which have been paid to them from time to time as also the amounts due from the agarias to the grocery shop are taken into account.

facts.text: Agarias work with families, free to engage extra labour and pay them; appellants have no involvement.

anchor.surface_text: The agarias work themselves with their families on the pattas allotted to them. They are free to engage extra labour but it is they who make the payments to these labourers and the appellants have nothing to do with the same.

facts.text: No prescribed hours of work, no muster roll, no control on hours/days worked.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants do not prescribe any hours of work for these agarias. No muster roll is maintained by them nor do they control how many hours in a day and for how many days in a month the agarias should work.

facts.text: No rules for leave or holidays; agarias free to leave if arrangements made.

anchor.surface_text: There are no rules as regards leave or holidays. They are free to go out of the works as they like provided they make satisfactory arrangements for the manufacture of salt.

facts.text: Disputes arose between agarias and appellants about 1950 regarding conditions of engagement.

anchor.surface_text: In about 1950, disputes arose between the agarias and the appellants as to the conditions under which the agarias should be engaged by the appellants in the manufacture of salt.

facts.text: Government of Saurashtra referred disputes to Industrial Tribunal by letter dated November 5, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Saurashtra, by its letter of Reference dated November 5, 1951, referred the disputes for adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Saurashtra State, Rajkot.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal held on August 30, 1952 that agarias are workmen and reference intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: This question was tried as a preliminary issue and by its order dated August 30, 1952, the Tribunal held that the agarias were workmen within the meaning of the Act and that the reference was intra vires and adjourned the matter for hearing on the merits.

facts.text: Appellants filed Appeal No. 302 of 1952 before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the appellants preferred an appeal being Appeal No. 302 of 1952, before the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India,

facts.text: High Court of Saurashtra dismissed M.P. No. 70 of 1952 on January 8, 1954, holding agarias are workmen.

anchor.surface_text: By their judgment dated January 8, 1954, the learned Judges of the High Court agreed with the decision of the Industrial Tribunal that the agarias were workmen within s. 2(s) of the Act and, accordingly, dismissed the application for writ.

facts.text: Facts as found by Industrial Tribunal are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts as found by the Industrial Tribunal are not in dispute and are as follows.
under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for an appropriate writ to quash the reference dated November 5, 1951, on the ground that it was without jurisdiction.
under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for an appropriate writ to quash the reference dated November 5, 1951, on the ground that it was without jurisdiction.
They, however, granted a certificate under Art. 133 1   c  of the Constitution and that is how the appeal comes before us.

Workman has been thus defined in s. 2  s  of the Act-  s  -Workman means any person employed  including an apprentice  in any industry to do any skilled or unskilled manual or clerical work for hire or reward and includes, for the purposes of any proceedings under this Act in relation to an industrial dispute, a workman discharged during that dispute, but does number include any person employed in the naval, military or air service of the  Government .

A distinction is also drawn between a contract for services and a contract of service and that distinction is put in this way In the one case the master can order or require what is to be done while in the other case he can number only order or require what is to be done but how itself it ,hall be done.

holdings.text: the agarias are not independent contractors but workmen within the meaning of the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show supervision and control by Salt Superintendent over density testing, pan preparation, crystal quality, and all stages of manufacture; evidence from Superintendent and agaria supports; applies control test and integration considerations

holdings.text: The question whether the relationship between the parties is one as between employer and employee or between master and servant is a pure question of fact

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the relationship between the parties is one as between employer and employee or between master and servant is a pure question of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Halsbury, Simmons v. Heath Laundry Co., rejects Batt's view as contrary to weight of authorities; Tribunal finding not to be interfered unless unsupported by evidence

holdings.text: far from there being no evidence to support the conclusion reached by the Industrial Tribunal there were materials on the record on the basis of which it could come to the conclusion that the agarias are workmen
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of Salt Superintendent and agaria Shiva Daya shows control at every stage from well sinking to salt collection; Clause 6 of agreement binds to instructions

holdings.text: a person can be a workman even though he is paid not per day but by the job. No distinction can be drawn from the circumstances of the man being employed at so much a day or by the job
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Sadler v. Henlock, Blake v. Thirst, Halsbury; payment mode irrelevant if control exists

holdings.text: while the former agrees himself to work, the latter agrees to get other persons to work... if he has, then he is a workman and the fact that he takes assistance from other persons would not affect his status

holdings.text: the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work

anchor.surface_text: the prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform test from authorities; Halsbury, Mersey Docks; control over manner key despite not universal

holdings.text: These difficulties, however, are not deterrent against holding the agarias to be workmen within the meaning of the definition if they fulfil its requirements
holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy issues like hours regulation secondary to statutory definition fulfillment

holdings.text: the decision of the Industrial Tribunal to the effect that the agarias are workmen within the definition of the term contained in s. 2(s) of the Act was justified on the materials on the record
holdings.reasoning_summary: Workmen status confers jurisdiction under s.10 for reference
